reasoning:
First off, Amazon lies well outside my circle of competence. I’m a simple fellow who likes to invest in businesses I can understand inside and out—soft drinks, insurance, railroads and the like. E-commerce platforms, cloud computing and the constant reinvestment cycle at Amazon feel more like rocket science than selling hamburgers or insuring cars. Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing, and I don’t know Amazon’s world as I do Coca-Cola or See’s Candies.

On the moat front, Amazon’s operating margins have been strong—averaging 38%—but its return on equity has been a modest 5.2% and returns on invested capital barely above 1%. That tells me pricing power in its cloud business doesn’t make up for razor-thin retail margins. A durable moat shows up in consistent high returns on capital, and Amazon’s numbers have swung all over the map.

Management is undoubtedly smart—Jeff Bezos has done remarkable things—but they plow almost every dollar back into new initiatives instead of returning capital to shareholders. I’ve never met a company that couldn’t find more ways to spend money, but my preference is for executives who act like owners and put money to work at high rates of return. Amazon’s debt-to-equity ratio of nearly 3-to-1 also gives me pause.

Financially, the story is mixed. You see inconsistent earnings growth and a weak ROE, offset only by book value growth. For a business to earn my wholehearted support, I want predictability, fortress-like balance sheets and consistent cash generation. That’s not plainly evident here.

Valuation is the clincher. Using a three-stage DCF, intrinsic value comes in around $4,740 a share, and yet Amazon trades near double that level. As I like to say, “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” Here, you’d be paying far more than the business is worth on a conservative estimate. A negative margin of safety of almost 100% is a flashing red light.

Long-term prospects? Undoubtedly Amazon will remain a big company. But big doesn’t always translate into great returns for shareholders. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than chase a complex operation at a lofty valuation.

Compared to opportunities in my portfolio—Coca-Cola selling at reasonable multiples or Apple yielding tidy returns—I see no compelling case for buying Amazon today. I’ll sit this one out.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 5.2%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.9; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 693.5% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 38.1%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
